#Text=Ms.
#Text=Power (United States of America): Madam\r
#Text=President, I would like thank the Secretary-General,\r
#Text=Special Representative Bangura, and Ms.
#Text=Misaka for\r
#Text=their informative and powerful briefings.
#Text=In the past decade, the Security Council has\r
#Text=identified the scourge of sexual violence in conflict as\r
#Text=a matter of acute and urgent concern.
#Text=We meet today to\r
#Text=assess progress in combating that pernicious form of\r
#Text=criminality and to consider next steps.
#Text=We begin with\r
#Text=confidence that the standards we have established are\r
#Text=clear and the terrible knowledge that those standards\r
#Text=are regularly being ignored.
#Text=We have made abundantly\r
#Text=clear that there should be zero tolerance for rape and\r
#Text=zero tolerance for other forms of sexual abuse in all\r
#Text=circumstances and at all times.
#Text=The terror of sexual\r
#Text=violence is uniquely horrific and merits our continued\r
#Text=and determined efforts to eliminate it.
#Text=Neither the fog\r
#Text=of war nor the associated breakdown of law provide\r
#Text=any explanation or excuse for actions that violate the\r
#Text=rights and disrespect the fundamental dignity of human\r
#Text=beings.
#Text=To articulate a zero-tolerance standard is, of course,\r
#Text=not difficult.
#Text=Indeed, we have done it many times.
#Text=But to\r
#Text=endow it with real meaning in real conflicts remains a\r
#Text=challenge of great urgency and one of many dimensions.
#Text=This is not work that should be delegated only to a Special\r
#Text=Representative of the Secretary-General on Sexual\r
#Text=Violence in Conflict, even one as capable as Special\r
#Text=Representative Bangura, or to women's protection\r
#Text=advisers in a peacekeeping mission or to UN-Women.
#Text=Those offices and officials and the United Nations as\r
#Text=a whole assuredly have an indispensable role to play,\r
#Text=but the key to further progress in reducing suffering\r
#Text=and in protecting the vulnerable is action by the parties\r
#Text=to conflict.
#Text=Every Government has a responsibility to\r
#Text=establish standards, develop institutions and pursue\r
#Text=policies that protect its people from sexual violence,\r
#Text=whether perpetrated by the Government's own forces\r
#Text=or by others.
#Text=That responsibility includes, as Special\r
#Text=Representative Bangura just put it, redirecting the\r
#Text=stigma from the survivors to the perpetrators.
#Text=That duty extends to men and boys, who have\r
#Text=suffered sexual violence to an extent we have only\r
#Text=recently begun to appreciate - in places like Colombia,\r
#Text=where boys were turned into sex slaves by illegal armed\r
#Text=groups; in Rutshuru, in the Democratic Republic of\r
#Text=the Congo, which was under the savage control of the\r
#Text=Mouvement du 23 mars for much of 2013; and in Libya,\r
#Text=where the United Nations reported that armed brigades\r
#Text=used rape in detention as a form of torture.
#Text=In far too many countries, the victims of sexual\r
#Text=violence still have little, if any, effective legal recourse.
#Text=Untilthat changes,predators willnotbe deterred, victims\r
#Text=will hesitate to come forward and justice will remain\r
#Text=beyond reach.
#Text=In places where Governments are weak,\r
#Text=we must help to improve their capabilities while also\r
#Text=holding accountable those who commit crimes.
#Text=Among\r
#Text=the most culpable are the ruthless militias in the Central\r
#Text=African Republic, whose assaults on civilians have\r
#Text=almost literally torn the country apart, and where rape,\r
#Text=forced marriage and sexual slavery are widespread; in\r
#Text=Burma, where there are widespread reports of soldiers\r
#Text=raping women and girls; and, as we have just heard, in\r
#Text=South Sudan, where only this week militants have gone\r
#Text=on the radio - radio, which my Rwandan colleague has\r
#Text=called an evil multiplier - to incite the use of sexual\r
#Text=violence against named ethnic groups; in Yemen, where\r
#Text=child protection workers have attested to the abduction\r
#Text=and abuse of boys by Ansar Al-Sharia.
#Text=With all of\r
#Text=that in mind, we should express special outrage at the\r
#Text=continued and widespread incidence of sexual abuse\r
#Text=practised by Syrian Government armed forces as part\r
#Text=of the regime's ruthless campaign to terrorize civilians\r
#Text=and drive families from their homes.
#Text=Despite chronic underreporting and difficulties of\r
#Text=access, we know more about the nature and scope of\r
#Text=the problem than ever before.
#Text=The Secretary-General's\r
#Text=report (S/2014/181), the information-collection\r
#Text=mechanisms on which it is based, and the steadfast\r
#Text=leadership shown by Special Representative Bangura\r
#Text=are all welcome developments.
#Text=In addressing sexual\r
#Text=violence, the United Nations must set the right\r
#Text=example in what it does both here in New York and in\r
#Text=places around the world where tensions are high and\r
#Text=United Nations peacekeepers or political missions are\r
#Text=deployed.
#Text=Ms.
#Text=Bangura has shown determination in\r
#Text=coordinating United Nations efforts across agencies\r
#Text=in order to ensure that the imperative of putting a stop\r
#Text=to sexual violence is addressed in training, included in\r
#Text=mission mandates and reports, and becomes a central\r
#Text=focus of enforcement activities and a major part of\r
#Text=holding perpetrators accountable for war crimes and\r
#Text=crimes against humanity.
#Text=As members of the Security Council, however, we\r
#Text=must do our part by exercising proper oversight and\r
#Text=pushing for the full implementation of the objectives\r
#Text=we set, mission by mission.
#Text=In that connection, I note\r
#Text=that women protection advisers were deployed last year\r
#Text=to Somalia and Mali, and are expected this year in the\r
#Text=Sudan, South Sudan, Cote d'Ivoire and the Central\r
#Text=African Republic.
#Text=In Somalia, the United Nations\r
#Text=has helped to train 12,000 police officers, and the\r
#Text=Government has supported the increased recruitment\r
#Text=of women police.
#Text=An improved effort has also been\r
#Text=made to strengthen investigative and prosecutorial\r
#Text=capabilities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo,\r
#Text=where sexual violence perpetrated by Government\r
#Text=and rebel forces has long been a source of chronic and\r
#Text=massive injustice.
#Text=We must also strive to help the Secretariat\r
#Text=achieve its goal of 20 per cent female participation\r
#Text=among United Nations police.
#Text=But for that to happen,\r
#Text=each of our countries must themselves increase their\r
#Text=recruitment of women police into their domestic forces,\r
#Text=so that there is a far broader pool on which the United\r
#Text=Nations can draw.
#Text=We must also insist on enforcing the\r
#Text=absolute prohibition on sexual abuse by United Nations\r
#Text=peacekeepers.
#Text=Again, that requires that home countries\r
#Text=hold perpetrators of sexual Violence accountable once\r
#Text=they are sent home.
#Text=In conclusion, I would like to voice the strong\r
#Text=support of my Government and of the American people\r
#Text=for a concerted strategy across the globe to address the\r
#Text=\r
#Text=problem of sexual violence, both in and outside combat\r
#Text=situations.
#Text=For far too long, such abuses have been\r
#Text=treated as part of the spoils of victory or the rewards\r
#Text=of physical might.
#Text=Let us be clear: sexual abuse is\r
#Text=among the worst of crimes, because it robs people of\r
#Text=the precious and inalienable right to be secure in their\r
#Text=bodies, and because it is inflicted out of cruelty.
#Text=In our\r
#Text=efforts to stop it, we have made gains in recent years,\r
#Text=but we have a very long way to go.
